Fields.DialogueText: Do you think the Kapitan will be okay?
The Captain was knocked unconscious by Yuri's bomb blast, but there weren't any other serious injuries.
What kind of crazy person would try to sink the same ship they are sailing on? How was Yuri even planning to survive after blowing up the ship?
I'm sure Yuri had some sort of escape planned. Weasels like him always think about saving their own skins before anything else...
We will keep Yuri locked in the brig until the Kapitan wakes up. If it were up to me, I would throw Yuri overboard - but the Kapitan is the only one who can decide what to do with him now.
Yuri is pretty high up in the Party, or at least that's what he claims. We're in a bit of a predicament now, since Moscow won't be too happy that we locked up their man.
Even after we explain that Yuri tried to blow up the ship and kill hundreds of Soviet sailors?
I... I don't want to get into any arguments with you, Voroshilov - but it seems like the lives of soldiers and sailors aren't worth too much in the Soviet Union.
How can you say that, Petty Officer Jones?! The whole reason for the Revolution is to improve life for all the people! It is just that sometimes... sacrifices must be made for the greater good.
Well, like I said, there's no need to debate politics right now. We both support the Captain, and that's what's important.
Da, Petty Officer Jones - and we must all work together to rid the world of these Rusalki!
Speaking of which, looks like there are some Morganas on the horizon...
Let us show the Rusalki the strength of humanity united under one dream!
@BATTLE
You were standing next to Yuri's last bomb when it exploded, Kapitan. You were knocked unconscious! I was so scared you might have been...
... I've got a bit of a headache, but it seems like my arms and legs are still attached.
Of course your arms and legs are still attached, Kapitan! Things would be much worse if they were not!
It was a figure of speech, Voroshilov. It's something you say when - ah, never mind! Was anyone else hurt in the explosion?
Nyet, Kapitan. You were the only one close enough to get hurt.
That's good to hear. How about you? Ship form, I mean. Any damage?
There is a hole in the deck. There was also a fire, but the crew put it out. We have already started on repairs.

Fields.MenuText: You've got the crew trained so well, it makes my job as Captain easy.
Things could have been a lot worse. Thanks for keeping things under control while I was out.
Yuri is crazy to have tried to blow up the ship! I'll make sure he pays for this!

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose walking the plank is not a very acceptable punishment these days, Kapitan?
We are a team, Kapitan! There is nothing we cannot accomplish if we work together towards a common goal.
You were not unconscious for very long, Kapitan. The crew continued to operate as usual according to our training.
Even after Yuri did what he did, he's still Moscow's representative on the ship. We'll need to sort things out with the Party to figure out what to do with him.
Da, Kapitan. I hope the Party will act quickly to remove Yuri and punish him for what he has done.
I hope so too. Until then, I'm perfectly within reason to keep Yuri in locked up. He just tried to sink the entire ship and crew, after all.
*BOOM*
Another one of Yuri's bombs?!
Nyet, Kapitan. It is incoming fire from approaching Rusalki - I can sense it. Please get some more rest. I will take care of the enemy!
Not alone you won't.
@BATTLE
Hey.
Kapitan! You're awake!
If I'd known you were watching over me I would've woken up sooner.
Really? Is that how it works with humans? I had no-
No, it's... sorry. Never mind. I'm not at my best. What happened?
But, Kapitan-
If I collapse, you can carry me back down here when the shooting stops.
I question the likely effect on the crew's morale... but so be it.
We have reported your actions to the Red Fleet, Yuri. I am sure they will agree that what you did are the actions of a madman. You will remain under guard until we are told to do otherwise.
You and this ship will always be a security risk, Comrade Voroshilov. As long as you have a mental connection with Marshal Voroshilov, we risk intelligence leaks at the highest level of the Party!
This idea that I can read Marshal Voroshilov's mind is completely false, Yuri. I have told you this countless times, and your experiments on me have failed to support your claims.
I don't care how high up you are in the Party, Yuri - trying to sink a Red Fleet ship while killing hundreds of Soviet sailors will be hard to justify to the leadership in Moscow.
My judgement is highly regarded in the Party, Kapitan. I am sure the Red Fleet will approve of my decision.

Fields.MenuText: Until then, we're keeping you locked up.
If the Red Fleet supports a crazy man like you, I'll resign as this ship's captain.
How were you planning to escape a sinking ship?

Fields.DialogueText: It's not very comfortable in here, Kapitan - but it will do for now.
Ha! Should I hold you to that, Kapitan?
I have many allies amongst your crew. We were prepared for the situation. Do not forget who is really in charge here, Kapitan.
Listen carefully. It's my job to protect Voroshilov, her crew, and the Black Sea. I take that extremely seriously.
You proved yourself to be a threat to these three things, Yuri. Right now it's very much in your interests to convince me that you are no longer a threat.
Oh, but I am a threat. A threat to anyone who is disloyal to my homeland. A threat to any potential spy or saboteur. And, yes, a threat to anyone who presumes to give such a one shelter or support.
You are a rat and a counterrevolutionary!
Ha! Counterrevolutionary? That is a very bold accusation, Comrade Voroshilov! You are lucky I am unable to record your words while locked up in this cell!
*BOOM*
We need to get back to the bridge to take care of these Morganas, Voroshilov!
You are an enemy of the people, Yuri Ivanovich! I can see through your lies!
@BATTLE
Are you threatening the Kapitan? How dare you? How *dare* you?!
Things got a bit heated in our last discussion with Yuri in the brig, huh?
I am sorry if I lost my temper, Kapitan. I will never forgive Yuri for what he did. Imagine if we lost you in that explosion...
I guarantee you that if anything takes me out of this world, it won't be a homemade bomb set off by an amateur like Yuri.
He is not an amateur, Kapitan. As much as I hate the man, he must have some talent if he climbed so high in the Party.
Don't confuse talent with ruthlessness and a lack of conscience, Voroshilov. It's easy to climb up the ladder when you don't have morals holding you back.
I am just glad Yuri is locked up and no longer a threat, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: It's nice to have more free time now that Yuri isn't running his experiments on you.
Now that Yuri isn't watching your every move, you can relax a little.
Oh, Yuri's still a threat - but I appreciate the relative peace and quiet.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan! I sat for so many hours as Yuri tried to monitor my thoughts with his machine - and he still failed to produce any evidence that I could read Marshal Voroshilov's mind!
It is strange having so much freedom now that I no longer have to sit for Yuri's constant experiments...
Yuri does talk a lot for a man who is always trying to spy on others...
Now that you have more free time with Yuri in the brig, it might be a good opportunity to relax a little. You have any hobbies?
A hobby, Kapitan?
Yes, a hobby - an activity you do just for fun!
My purpose is to fight, Kapitan. I am fighting for the people, supporting the Revolution and destroying the Rusalki who stand in the way of our freedom and progress.
This concept of a hobby sounds like a waste of valuable time that would be better spent supporting our mission.
Well, you're in luck because it looks like we've got some Morganas approaching.
My favorite hobby, Kaptain - sinking Rusalki!
@BATTLE
You were the one he was trying to kill.
I don't take that part personally.
That's okay. I do.
I'm not human, Kapitan. I exist to serve, and I'm not easy to break. You, on the other hand-
Shooting the Rusalki is fun.
Not exactly what I had in mind.
Talking with you while we work is fun.
Thank you. Likewise.
But I think you could still use something to take your mind off politics and the war for a while.
But-
There are practical effects, you know. If you can find a way to relax, I promise that you come back to work with even more energy!
I had another dream last night, Kapitan.
Another dream of Marshal Voroshilov's memories?
Da, Kapitan. I have never been able to read Marshal Voroshilov's mind in the present day, but I do have dreams of his memories from time to time.
Hopefully it wasn't as traumatic as that last one about the fighting in Finland.
Nyet, Kapitan, but the dream was still... unsettling.
I'm sorry to hear that...
In my hands, or should I say Marshal Voroshilov's hands, he held a piece of paper with 13 names. It was dated 1937. He signed his name at the bottom.

Fields.MenuText: It was from 1937? That was in the middle of Stalin's purges...
What's so unsettling about signing an order? I'm sure he's signed many of them in his time with the Party.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan. Many were purged from the Party during this time.
The order was from 1937, Kapitan. It was during the Yezhovshchina - when many were purged from the Party.

Fields.MenuText: I sign off on so many things as a captain - sometimes I have unsettling dreams about paperwork too!

Fields.DialogueText: This dream was not a laughing matter, Kapitan.
The list of names was an execution order - one of the many that Marshal Voroshilov must have signed in his lifetime.
I can't imagine being personally responsible for ordering the deaths of so many people...
That is why I will never be able to understand my namesake, Kapitan. The Party accused many of crimes during this time, but I am sure not all of them were guilty...
... but there was one name at the bottom of the list that I remember clearly - Yuri Ivanovich Volkov.
Yuri was on the list to be purged, but somehow escaped being executed?

Da, Kapitan! I am sure Yuri bribed or blackmailed his way out of the situation - but it explains why Yuri was so insistent on getting rid of me! Marshal Voroshilov personally ordered Yuri's execution!
*ALARM*
Now that's a interesting bit of information! Let's take care of these Morganas, then head down to the brig to have a word with Yuri!
@BATTLE
Marshal Voroshilov ordered your execution in 1937, Yuri Ivanovich! I saw him sign the order for you to be purged.
What?! How were you able to see something from so long ago? This must mean you really can read Marshal Voroshilov's mind!
Nyet, Yuri. I only have dreams of his memories - it is the same strange phenomena as any other Comrade of the Fleet named after a real person.
You are a threat to the Party! You are a threat to the entire Soviet Union! This is why you belong at the bottom of the Black Sea, Voroshilov!

Fields.MenuText: It sounds like Voroshilov is only a threat to your future in the Party.
So you're admitting that what Voroshilov saw is true?
Calm down, Yuri - or we'll make sure you end up on the bottom of the Black Sea!

Fields.DialogueText: We cannot have security leaks like this, Kapitan! This chatterbox is a godsend for spies!
I will admit nothing to you, Kapitan!
Voroshilov is a huge risk to the people, Kapitan! We cannot allow this situation to continue!
Marshal Voroshilov approved of your execution, but somehow here you are today, Mr. Yuri...
The two things we can conclude are that you managed to anger enough Party members to get on a list to be purged in the first place, and that you somehow weaseled your way out of getting executed.
Please have mercy, Kapitan! That was so long ago now! The Party must never hear about this!
It is too late, Yuri Ivanovich. The Kapitan has already sent a report about my dream to the Party!
How... how could you do such a thing?! Do you understand what they will do to me?
We are not here to judge you, Yuri. The orders from the Party were to regularly report on my actions and mental activity - and that is exactly what the Kapitan did!
@BATTLE
Captain! We've got new orders from headquarters.
Thank you, Petty Officer Jones. Let me take a look...
What do they say, Kapitan?
The Red Fleet is still sorting out what to do with Yuri... we're to continue our patrol and engage any Morganas we see... and await further instructions from HQ.
So Moscow doesn't know what to do with him either?
I am sure they will decide whatever is in the best interest of the Soviet Union.

Fields.MenuText: It's in their best interest to kick rotten apples like Yuri out of the Party.
I'm sure there's a lot of politics behind the decision, even if it's obvious that Yuri is no good.
Yuri is dead weight and eats too much - it would save us fuel and food to dump him overboard.

Fields.DialogueText: As much as I would like to, you know we could never do something like that, Kapitan - at least not without official direction from the Party...
The old men in Moskva always make things more complicated than they have to be, Kapitan.
Da, Kapitan! The Party must only be led by the best to ensure a bright future for the Soviet Union!
All we can do for now is follow orders and keep patroling the Black Sea for Morganas.
Lady Voroshilov, it must be a relief not to have Yuri hooking up wires to your brain and monitoring you all the time!
I have been monitored ever since I appeared. Having so much free time and freedom now is... a strange feeling. The Kapitan suggested I find something called a "hobby" to occupy myself...
Ah, a hobby! That's a grand idea! I can help you figure something out, Lady Voroshilov!
Why thank you, Petty Officer Jones! I admit I am not an expert in this area. May I ask you what your hobbies are?
Um... mostly drinking, smoking, and playing cards - but we can find you something a lot more productive and fitting for being the Lady of the Ship!
*GUNFIRE*
I appreciate your help, Petty Officer Jones! Let us get started with this "hobby" right away - as soon as we sink these Rusalki!
@BATTLE
It is strange to keep Yuri locked away even though we are docked, Kapitan.
But the situation is what it is. We've got to keep him in our custody until the Party decides what they want us to do with him.
Whatever they decide, I am sure we will just hand Yuri over to Party representatives and then never hear of him again.
That's not such a bad thing, Lady Voroshilov! With Yuri gone, now you've got some time to find a hobby!
I am still having difficulty understanding this concept of a "hobby."
Well... your namesake Marshal Voroshilov is a cavalry officer. He probably loves riding horses. A lot of ladies relax by riding horses too. Maybe you can try horseback riding?
Brilliant idea, Captain! Maybe I can find a horse in town and bring it to the ship so Lady Voroshilov can go for a short little ride around the deck!

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure she'll love it! What lady doesn't like riding horses?
We've got a few hours before we're scheduled to depart, so why not give it try?
Voroshilov is always so serious. Maybe a quick little ride will loosen her up a bit.

Fields.DialogueText: Sounds like a plan, Captain! I'm sure it won't take very long to find a horse around here...
This'll be too much fun, Captain! I'll try and find a horse we can borrow for an hour or two...
All she knows is how to be a lab rat and how to run a warship, Captain - but some horseback riding might put a smile on her face!
Why has no one asked me if I actually want to ride a horse? Everyone is always telling me what to do - Voroshilov must be monitored, Voroshilov must report her dreams, Voroshilov must have a hobby...
A hobby is the exact opposite of telling you what to do! We're just trying to show you a few options to get you started, that's all.
*GUNFIRE*
Let us take care of the Rusalki in the harbor while Petty Officer Jones looks for this horse - but I am telling you that fighting is the only hobby I need, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Believe me, there's a big part of me that would love to say that the guy was under Morgana influence and is a League problem rather than a Soviet problem.
But he wasn't.
No. But the poetic justice of having a League science team lock him up and poke at him to see if there were outside influences acting on his brain...
Ooooooh.
So Voroshilov, you didn't enjoy the horseback riding?
The horse did not want to go in the same direction that I wanted... if I can walk on my own feet faster and with less effort, what is the purpose of riding a horse?
I'm more of a sailor than a horse rider myself, but riding a horse should be faster and less effort if you do it right...
Lady Voroshilov and the horse had a difficult time understanding each other, Captain.
If I wanted to go straight, the horse would stop. If I wanted to turn left, the horse would turn right...

Fields.MenuText: It just takes practice. A good horse and rider move together as a team.
Once you and the horse understand each other, a horse is much faster than walking yourself.
Ha! If you think one horse is tough, try being a captain and leading a whole crew and ship!

Fields.DialogueText: It seems like a waste of time to explain my intentions to the horse every time I want to move, Kapitan.
How can a horse ever understand the intentions of a person, Kapitan? I am not sure they are capable of such complex thought.
At least you can speak to the crew, Kapitan! The horse did not seem to understand when I spoke Russkiy yazyk...
I think you're underestimating the intelligence of horses, Voroshilov! A good horse and rider are perfectly in sync with each other - almost like the horse can read the rider's mind!
It seems like everyone in the Soviet Union speaks about science as a way to understand the world - but then mind reading seems perfectly believable!
Well... not literal mind reading, Lady Voroshilov - but a well-trained horse can pick up on signals from the rider.
Perhaps this horse was not well-trained then, Petty Officer Jones.
Maybe horseback riding isn't going to be the relaxing hobby I thought it would be for you, Voroshilov...
*ALARM*
Fighting the Rusalki will always be a relaxing hobby for me, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Chess is complicated, Kapitan. The rules also seem very arbitrary.
I promise, I'll walk you through them. Maybe it can be as much a joint leadership exercise as a new hobby. Go ahead - it's your move.
I do not understand why Lenin enjoyed this game so much...
Well, Lenin was a thinker, and chess definitely takes a lot of thinking! The best players in the world can plan a dozen moves ahead - it's a very strategic game.
This game for royalists! The queen is the most powerful piece, the bishops and nobles are required to win, the game is over when the king dies, and the proletariat are weak pawns to be sacrificed!

Fields.MenuText: Hmm... I never thought about chess like that before...
Well, Lenin did believe we needed to get rid of kings to win...
True - but we still need a strong vanguard party to lead the revolution!

Fields.DialogueText: Chess represents the exploitative imperialist systems that we are struggling to dismantle, Kapitan!
Da, Kapitan - but chess is just one kingdom against another! No matter which king wins, the proletariat is still enslaved!
A king and queen will never lead a revolution for the proletariat, Kapitan!
I never thought there was so much class struggle in chess.
How could you not? It's explicitly a model of the feudal mode of production!
There are no "modes of production" in chess, Voroshilov. It's just a game.
Nothing is "just a game!" It is indifferent attitudes like this that are holding us back!
*ALARM*
No time for debate right now - we need to get to the bridge! We can get back to this game later.
Chess is not just a game, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Rowing this lifeboat hardly seems like a relaxing hobby, Kapitan!
Apparently Lenin also liked rowing, so I thought we could try it out to see if it could be your hobby too.
If rowing is so relaxing, why are you and Petty Officer Jones not down here in the boat with me? This feels like a man overboard drill, Kapitan - except there is no one to rescue!
The water is a bit choppy down there, Captain! These conditions aren't exactly like a relaxing row down the Thames...

Fields.MenuText: Good point. Maybe this was another bad idea.
Lenin liked physical hobbies that were also productive. That seems to be in line with how Voroshilov thinks.
Maybe she would find it more fun if we threw someone overboard to rescue...

Fields.DialogueText: It would be hard to find a volunteer in these waters, Kapitan - but we could always volunteer Yuri!
Voroshilov might not be motivated enough to fish him out though - then we'd be in big trouble with the Party.
It's going to be hard to find another hobby that Voroshilov likes more than shooting at Morganas, Captain.
Maybe, but I'm not going to give up yet! Voroshilov has never had a chance to enjoy free time on her own, so I at least want to show her what that's like.
I understand, Captain, but trying to row around in these rough seas is neither fun nor productive!
I suppose even Lenin didn't go rowing in the middle of the Black Sea...
... Okay, Voroshilov! It's obvious that you're not having too much fun down there, so come alongside so we can hoist you back up!
I told you before we started that this would be a waste of time, Kapitan!
My apologies, Voroshilov! I thought it might be fun!
*SPLASH*
*BOOM*
Oh! Da! As you say!
@BATTLE
Where did she-
Are you all right, Kapitan?!
Bloody hell!
Belle teleportation. It's a thing. I'm fine, Voroshilov - the blast wasn't that close.
Good. Very good.
But we should get to the bridge.
Fishing, Kapitan?
Yes - fishing! Lenin loved hunting, but unfortunately fishing is the closest we can do out here. He loved hunting because it was a physical hobby that was also productive.
Productive for the hunter - not very productive for the prey.
Well, yes... anyway, you seem more concerned with your time being productive than fun, so I thought we could try one of the most productive hobbies of them all - fishing!
How is fishing productive, Kapitan?

Fields.MenuText: It's one of the most primitive and practical hobbies out there! If you can't hunt or fish, you can't eat!
It's a way to relax and enjoy nature while also putting food on the table.
It's always an exciting fight when you hook a big fish!

Fields.DialogueText: Now you have my interest, Kapitan! I love a good fight!
I see! So the better we are at this fishing hobby, the more we can eat? It does seem very productive!
I do enjoy the sound of the ocean and the feeling of the wind in my hair, Kapitan!
Great! So it sounds like you're willing to give fishing a try?
Whether it is Yuri or you, I will always be told what to do on this ship. It is pointless to ask if I am "willing" to do anything when I will inevitably be forced to do it anyway.
I'm just helping to show you all the things you can do in your free time, Voroshilov! Now that Yuri's locked up, you've got complete freedom to do what you want.
I understand, Kapitan. I did not mean to criticize your efforts to help find a hobby for me - but perhaps I am a little frustrated that none of your ideas seem to be suitable.
Fishing does sound like it could be exciting, though! So what do I do now? How do I do this "fishing" hobby?
Well, you just hold the pole still and keep the line in the water - just like you have it now.
... Okay. Then what do I do next?
You don't do anything. You just wait like that... until you get a bite from a fish.
How long will this waiting be?
It could be a few minutes... a few hours...
*GUNFIRE*
We are finding Rusalki much faster than finding fish, Kapitan! Fighting is still the best hobby for me!
@BATTLE
I don't mean to force you!
Ah, Kapitan! So nice of you to come and visit me in my delightful cell!
I just wanted to make sure you're doing okay down here, Yuri. We're still waiting on orders from the Red Fleet telling us what to do with you.
Well, aside from being confined, I suppose things are fine, Kapitan.
You speak so casually for someone who almost killed hundreds of sailors by trying to sink a Red Fleet ship!
That was all in the past, Comrade Voroshilov! Can we not move on and think about the future?
It's been a matter of weeks since you tried to blow up the ship! Your past is full of such crimes, and you will not be forgiven for any of them!
A matter of weeks? That is an eternity in this war, Comrade Voroshilov!

Fields.MenuText: The Party is still debating what to do with you after learning you escaped execution back in 1937...
If you think we'll forget you tried to blow us all up, you're even more delusional than we thought.

Fields.DialogueText: That was more than two years ago! Why does everyone expend so much energy holding onto the past?

Fields.MenuText: We just report on the situation and follow orders, Yuri. It's up to the Party to judge you now.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps I overreacted a bit, Kapitan... is it too late to ask for forgiveness?
I have my ways of getting out of these kinds of situations, Kapitan...
You're my responsibility while you're on this ship, but we'll eventually go back to Sevastopol and turn you over to the Party.
What happens from there isn't anything I have control over. I don't really care what happens to you either - I just want you off my ship.
I seem to have worn out my welcome, Kapitan.
I am sure this is not the first time you have done so, Yuri. You will be lucky if the Party decides that Siberia is enough of a punishment.
My only mistake was not getting rid of you earlier, Comrade Voroshilov...
You are a rat and a counterrevolutionary, Yuri! Opportunists like you have no place in the Party!
@BATTLE
You were pretty critical about chess the first time we played it, so I was surprised that you wanted to give it another try.
Chess becomes more interesting the more I learn about it. Perhaps this is the reason why Lenin enjoyed it so much. It is your turn, Kapitan.
Oh, right... I'm going to castle on the king's side. I haven't gone over the rules for that with you yet, but let me show you...
You can move two pieces at the same time? The king moves two spaces, then the rook moves to the opposite side to protect the king? All the rules in this game are about preserving the monarchy!

Fields.MenuText: You see class conflict in everything, don't you?
So you're finally admitting that chess is just a game?

Fields.DialogueText: Class struggle is evident in most things, Kapitan. It will continue to be this way as long as the capitalists control the means of production while exploiting the labor of the working class.
It is not so much a game as a metaphor for the struggle between the feudal elite and the peasant class, Kapitan. No matter which side wins in chess, a king will always be victorious!

Fields.MenuText: The king just represents a leadership - think of it like the Politburo.

Fields.DialogueText: True socialism is an expression of the people as a collective, Kapitan. It should not rely on the decisions of a single man, and certainly not a man chosen simply because of his royal birth!
Class conflict aside, castling is a good strategy to protect your king. Don't do it right away, though - see how your opponent deploys their pieces first before deciding which direction to castle.
So you can castle in either direction?
Yes - you can castle on the king's side or the queen's side.
But no matter which direction you choose, it is always to strengthen the king's position?
Well, yes... if that's how you'd like to phrase it.
Chess is an indoctrination tool of the feudalists, Kapitan! I do not understand why Lenin would enjoy such a game! I do not even understand why the capitalists enjoy it!
*BOOM*
Let's get to the bridge, Voroshilov! The only struggle we have to worry about right now is against the Morganas!
@BATTLE
Maybe music would be a more relaxing hobby for you, Voroshilov. You just have to sit and listen, but it's a little more exciting than the sitting we did when we were fishing.
I have not listened to very much music, Kapitan - although sometimes I hear the sailors listening to the radio.
A lot of people like listening to music. It's hard to explain, but music makes you feel different emotions just by hearing it. Let me turn on my gramophone...
I normally do not feel very many emotions, Kapitan. I am not sure what this music will do for me...
Hmm... you do keep your emotions on an even keel most of the time - except when you talk to Yuri! Music is usually about positive emotions, though - not the anger you feel with Yuri.
I see... so what is this we are listening to now?
Swan Lake, a ballet by Tchaikovsky. The music goes along with dancing, and it tells a story.
A story? What is the story of Swan Lake, Kapitan?
Well, a prince falls in love with a princess who is under a curse from an evil sorcerer. The curse transforms the princess into a swan every day, although she turns back into a human every night.
The curse can be broken if someone who has never loved before falls in love with the princess. The prince wants to break the curse, and plans to declare his love to the princess.
Unfortunately, the sorcerer tricks the prince into first declaring his love to the sorcerer's own daughter, who is secretly disguised to look just like the princess.
The real princess is now distraught that she can't marry the prince, so she drowns herself in a lake. The prince then realizes he can only join the princess in death, so he drowns himself too.
Kapitan... that sounds like a horrible story! What is the lesson of Swan Lake - that men are liars and cheats?

Fields.MenuText: It's one of the most beautiful pieces of music ever composed!
... I suppose it doesn't make men look good.
Let's focus on the music instead of the story... the dancing is great too!

Fields.DialogueText: I do like the music, but knowing the story makes the whole experience quite tragic, Kapitan...
The sorcerer reminds me of Yuri, Kapitan - full of tricks, lies, and deception!
It would be interesting to see the dancing that goes along with the music, Kapitan...
Maybe it's not the most uplifting story, but the whole experience is just... so moving! The music and dancing makes you think about the amazing beauty and tragedy of love and life!
This is sounds like too much emotion for me, Kapitan! Music does not seem very relaxing at all!
*ALARM*
I am at my most relaxed when we are in battle with the Rusalki, Kapitan! Let us return to the fight!
@BATTLE
How are things going with the Captain's project to find a hobby for you, Voroshilov?
It has been interesting, but no activity seems to be more relaxing to me than fighting the Rusalki.
Really? None of the Captain's ideas have been any good?
Well, you seem to like chess. I wouldn't go so far as to say you're having fun, but you seem to be enjoying it in your own way.
Da, Kapitan. Chess has been a productive experience! One has to understand the pre-socialist modes of production in order to devise strategies to dismantle them.

Fields.MenuText: Now you're sounding a lot like Lenin!

Fields.DialogueText: I am beginning to appreciate how much there is to learn from chess. Lenin must have seen the same things.

Fields.MenuText: You seem relaxed when you're thinking about your next move.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan. Too much emotion over decisions will cloud my thought and lead to errors.

Fields.MenuText: But you have started castling to protect your king!

Fields.DialogueText: It is a practical strategy to put me in a better position to win, Kapitan. The proletariat would never keep the king in charge after seizing power.
Seems like you've given chess a lot of thought, Lady Voroshilov! I admit that I'm more of a checkers gal myself - it's easier to play if you've already had a drink or two!
Do not worry, Petty Officer Jones! The vanguard party will fight for the benefit of all people - even the people who find chess too difficult to understand!
In any case, should I check around the supply yard to see if-
I can see ships approaching on the horizon, Kapitan. They look like Rusalki...
Let's hurry up and get back on board then. We'll have to clear those Morganas out of the harbor before we can go anywhere!
@BATTLE
Nyet. Not now.
We haven't had much luck with Lenin's old hobbies, so I thought we might give some of Stalin's hobbies a try.
It seems like you will not stop suggesting new hobbies until we find one that suits me, so I will continue to humor you, Kapitan.
I know I'm pushing this hard, but ever since we locked Yuri up, you've just seemed so... lost when you didn't have something to shoot. You deserve to be having some fun.
We are fighting a war - I am not sure why I also need to be having fun.
If all you do is focus on fighting, well... it's not healthy at all! That's when sailors stop feeling like normal people...
I will trust your judgement, Kapitan. So what new hobby are we trying today?
Stalin loves food and cooking. We'll make one of his favorite dishes, shashlik - skewered meat cubes roasted over a charcoal grill! I've already got the fire going, and the lamb is ready to cook.
So the hobby is cooking this meat over a grill? This seems much less efficient than eating the food the cooks have already prepared in the mess hall.

Fields.MenuText: It's fun to be in charge of the whole cooking process!
It takes more time, but food tastes better when you cook it yourself.
Most people don't have the luxury of other people cooking for them - that's mostly for the bourgeoisie!

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps, Kapitan - but cooking shashlik is still mostly standing around and waiting. Grilling meat must have been invented by the same men who thought fishing was fun.
I am not sure about that, Kapitan. If I have never cooked before, how can my cooking result in better food than a professional chef? I am a bit skeptical...
Sailors and soldiers are hardly part of the bourgeoisie, Kapitan! We are vanguards of the Revolution! The food served in the mess is not exactly luxurious...
The skewers don't have to cook for very long. Once they're done and you take a bite, I think you'll see how fun cooking can be.
Until then, we will wait, Kapitan...
Yep. It's a good thing I like spending-
*GUNFIRE*
We can always count on the Morganas to ruin a picnic...
What a relief! Let us get back to fighting, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
So cooking wasn't very fun either?
Nyet, Kapitan. The shashlik did taste good, but the cooking process was more boring than fun.
Hmm... sorry about that. I thought you'd at least appreciate being out on the deck and cooking in the open air.
That was enjoyable, Kapitan - I always like being outside. Oh, it is your turn...

At least we still have chess. Okay, I'm going to teach you a new move - it's called "en passant." You just moved your pawn two squares to avoid my pawn, so normally I wouldn't be able to attack you...
... but with "en passant," I can move my pawn behind your pawn diagonally like this, and then capture your piece.
That is cheating, Kapitan! That goes against the rules for how pawns move and capture other pieces.
Well, yes... it's normally against the rules, but it's a legal move in this situation.
"En passant" seems like... backstabbing, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: En passant exists to counter exactly what you just did - trying to avoid my pawn by moving two squares.

Fields.DialogueText: It seems like you keep creating new rules as we go along, Kapitan!

Fields.MenuText: I only backstabbed your pawn because it tried to run away!

Fields.DialogueText: Attacking someone from behind is never an honorable thing to do, Kapitan!

Fields.MenuText: I don't make the rules - I just follow them.

Fields.DialogueText: That is an easy thing to say when you are the only one who knows all the rules, Kapitan!
I'm sorry there are so many rules to chess, but I think that's the last big one I had left to explained to you.
Why are the pawns so busy backstabbing each other and holding each other back while the feudal elite control all the territory on the board?
Well, the pawns can be very strong if they work together. If they stand together in a chain, like I've got here, then it makes it difficult for the... "elite" pieces to move freely!
I see! Chess really is about class conflict, Kapitan! Lenin must have learned so much from this game!
@BATTLE
So what's this game called again, Captain?
It's called "gorodki," Petty Officer Jones. It's a popular Russian lawn game. Voroshilov is starting to appreciate chess, so I thought I'd introduce her to one of Stalin's favorite games.
So how do we play, Kapitan?
It's simple. The "gorod" or "city" is the square I marked over there. In the square are wooden pins called "gorodki" or "little cities."
So we stand over here, and we throw this big wooden bat at the pins to knock them out of the square. Whoever can clear out the square in the least number of throws wins.
So the game is literally destroying entire cities? This does sound like a game Stalin would love...
Just think of it as lawn bowling, Petty Officer Jones. Voroshilov has already given far too much thought to the class struggle that chess represents...
But in this game, the army that destroys cities the fastest is the victor?

Fields.MenuText: If you use the Russian terms for the pieces, then yes.
It's just lawn bowling. Let's not overthink gorodki like you did with chess.
Yes, Stalin has a lot of fun playing it.

Fields.DialogueText: I am sure there are strategies to learn here - just like chess, Kapitan!
There are many ways to destroy cities, Kapitan. I am sure it is useful to think about the most efficient methods...
Chess and gorodki are very useful training for our fight against the capitalists, Kapitan!
I just thought that gorodki could be a good way for us to get some sunshine and exercise, Voroshilov.
The Russians sure do have strange ways of having fun, Captain.
Voroshilov, you can go ahead and take the first throw.
Okay, Kapitan - here I go!
*THUNK*
*SPLASH*
I forgot how strong Belles can be...
She knocked all those little cities clear off the deck and into the water, Captain!
I am sorry, Kapitan! Sometimes I forget my own strength!
Unless you want to send a dive team to the bottom of the Black Sea to fish out those pins, I think the game's over for now, Captain!
... Well, let's scratch gorodki off the list for potential hobbies. Apparently it only takes a Belle one throw to sink an entire city...
@BATTLE
You really think any possible hobby has to be connected to Lenin or Stalin to have a chance?
I think context doesn't hurt.
Gardening is a lot less physical than playing gorodki, so I don't think you'll end up accidentally knocking anything overboard this time.
I agree, but do you really think gardening can be an enjoyable hobby, Kapitan?
Yes! As much as Stalin loves cooking and playing gorodki, he also finds gardening to be very relaxing.
I see, but how can we even try to garden on a ship, Kapitan?
We've still got sunshine and rain out here, so I had the sailors prepare a few planters full of dirt. We can grow whatever you want!
I have never gardened before. What kinds of things can we plant? I would prefer if our garden contributes to the overall war effort, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: We can plant healthy vegetables to help feed the crew.
Perhaps some fruit to break up the monotony of the mess hall food?
Flowers are out of the question, then. They look pretty, but that's about it.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan - I would prefer to spend our efforts on crops that will help us fight! Flowers are an extravagant luxury. Let us plant potatoes and cabbages then!
That is a good idea, Kapitan! We will plant potatoes and cabbages... and beets!
Da! Perhaps we can plant strawberries, Kapitan?
You sound more excited than I expected, Voroshilov! You didn't like fishing or cooking because of all the waiting, so I didn't know what to expect with gardening.
It is like the proletarian revolution, Kapitan - we must plant the seeds now, and tend our fields until we can finally harvest our results.
So you're saying there's class struggle in potato planting too?
Da, Kapitan! Who is planting the potatoes, and who will benefit from the harvest?

We've just got a few planters on the deck, Voroshilov. It shouldn't take us too long to plant some fruit and vegetables if we work together - and of course we'll share it all with the crew when it's time to harvest.
You are a true socialist, Kapitan! This gardening hobby is very instructive!
We're just talking about potatoes, Voroshilov...
*GUNFIRE*
Rusalki ahead, Kapitan! We must defend our potatoes from the counterrevolutionaries!
@BATTLE
Your turn, Kapitan.
Oh! There's one last rule that I forgot to mention!
I feel like you are making up new rules whenever they suit you, Kapitan!
No, I promise I'm playing fair! There are just a lot of little rules in chess, so it's hard to explain everything at once.
I suppose I have no choice but to trust you... what is the new rule this time?
Well, do you see my pawn here? It's almost to your side of the board. So if I move it one more square to the edge, then I can promote it to a queen.
T-foo! How can you just tell me this now, Kapitan?! That is a crazy rule!

Fields.MenuText: Just think of it as a proletarian revolution!
Doesn't it give you hope that the least powerful piece can get promoted to royalty?
Sorry - I forgot to mention this rule until just now.

Fields.DialogueText: I find that very hard to believe, Kapitan! You mean to tell me that as you slowly advanced your pawn, knowing that it would be promoted, you conveniently forgot to mention this rule to me?
Hmm... it does feel good to see the working class rise up to seize power, but I still think you should have mentioned this rule earlier, Kapitan!
It is not a revolution if we only replace one monarch with another - even if the new king came from humble origins. This rule greatly changes the game though! You should have mentioned it earlier!
Promotion is a very powerful rule in chess, and I'm sorry I didn't explain it earlier. I swear I wasn't intentionally keeping it a secret from you.
It is still a nice thought though, is it not? A lowly pawn can struggle to advance across the field, and finally seize power to counter the royalists and the capitalists!
I'm pretty sure they weren't thinking about that when they came up with the rules for pawn promotion...
*ALARM*
Leave the pieces where they are, Kapitan! We will finish the game after taking care of these Rusalki!
@BATTLE
Yuri is gone?! What do you mean?
I went down to the brig to check on Yuri, and he's not in his cell, Captain! One of Yuri's spies on the crew must have broken him out!
He must know that the Party will judge him harshly for his crimes, Kapitan. Yuri's only way to survive is to escape before we get back to Russia and turn him over to the Party.
We've got to search the entire ship immediately! Yuri could be hiding anywhere.
Don't worry, Captain. He's a slippery little rat, but we'll get him!

Fields.MenuText: Check the berths and all the storage areas, especially for our munitions. I won't have another bomb plot.
Secure all the lifeboats - Yuri might use one to get away.
Pay attention to any unusual radio traffic - Yuri might call for help.

Fields.DialogueText: On it, Captain. We won't give him a chance to hide.
I suppose we're close enough to shore that Yuri could row his way back to land...
Will do, Captain!
We need to act fast! He's either going to run or he's going to try to hurt Voroshilov again, and I've got no damn patience for either.
*BOOM*
Another one of Yuri's bombs?
Nyet, Kapitan - incoming fire from Rusalki!
@BATTLE
Ssh. Just give me a moment. He's like an itch on my back. I just need to...
Is she doing another psychic thing?
I think she's doing a Belle thing. Sometimes they're able to find onboard when they-
Damn it! I can't believe Yuri jumped into a lifeboat that fast!
He got the jump on us, Captain! But it looks like he's on his own, so he's not rowing very quickly.
It is still not too far to get back to shore. We need to stop him before he escapes, Kapitan!
Ah hell! We're tied up fighting the biggest fleet of Morganas we've run into in months, not to mention all the mines in the water...
We can't move the ship very easily, Lady Voroshilov! One wrong move and we hit a mine or run straight into a line of Morganas!
... Gorodki, Kapitan!
Gorodki? Now's definitely not the time for lawn games, Voroshilov!
Nyet, Kapitan - do you still have the gorodki bat? I know I knocked all the pins into the ocean by accident, but I think the gorodki bat fell onto the deck.
Well, yes... the gorodki bat is just over there by the railing - but we need to concentrate on sinking these Morganas so to we can catch up to Yuri!
I was pretty good at throwing the gorodki bat, Kapitan! Yuri is still not too far away - I think I can knock him unconscious with a good throw!

Fields.MenuText: The bat is right over there. Watch your strength and try not to take his head off!
You really think you can hit him from here?
Hobbies do come in handy, don't they?

Fields.DialogueText: I will only use as much strength as necessary, Kapitan!
If I can land artillery shells accurately on the horizon, landing a gorodki bat on Yuri's head will not be difficult!
Da, Kapitan! Thank you for teaching me how to relax with this gorodki hobby - it has proven useful for knocking Yuri out!
All right, Voroshilov - we're counting on you! Commence gorodki bat firing!
I will not fail you, Kapitan! Humph!
*THUNK*
*SPLASH*
Unbelievable! You got Yuri right on the back of the head! Lights out! Incredible throw, Lady Voroshilov!
... Okay. Now we just need to go out there and grab Yuri out of that lifeboat before he tips overboard in his sleep.
I can go get Yuri, Kapitan - but first we must clear a safe path through all these Rusalki!
@BATTLE
You really are amazing. You know that?
Kapitan?
It was good to give Lady Voroshilov those rowing lessons earlier, Captain - she's almost rowed over to Yuri's boat already.
That's great! The Morganas keep coming, so we need to sink any of them that get too close to her.
Aye aye, Captain! That line of Morganas is heading straight for her, so let's start firing!
@BATTLE
Rowing is fun after all, Kapitan!
Welcome back aboard, Voroshilov! I would welcome Yuri too, but it looks like he's still out cold.
The gorodki bat hit Yuri right on the back of the head, Kapitan. His heart is still beating and he is breathing normally, so I think he should wake up soon enough.
Have the sailors lock Yuri back up up in the brig, Petty Officer Jones.
Aye aye, Captain! I'm happy to lock this weasel up for a second time!
Thank you for showing me the rowing hobby, Kapitan. Much like gorodki, it is a very useful skill.

Fields.MenuText: Gorodki was more of a suprise than rowing, but I'm glad both were useful.
I guess rowing is more interesting for you when there's a purpose.
I still can't get over how accurate you were with that gorodki bat!

Fields.DialogueText: Knowing how to attack cities and row boats will always be good things for a warship, Kapitan. They are very fun hobbies after all!
Da, Kapitan - a warship does not sortie to go on a pleasure cruise!
Yuri did not even see it coming - although I wish he did, Kapitan!
Y'know, I think we could even say you caught a big fish in the end.
That sounds like an excellent idea, Kapitan!
Why would we?

Fields.MenuText: Sorry. Just entertaining myself.
Just completing the hobby theme.
Because the metaphor ends with Yuri being gutted and fried, and that amuses me.

Fields.DialogueText: Anyway - good work today, Voroshilov! Let's get back to Russia to get rid of Yuri for good.
The Party officials didn't say too much when they took Yuri away, but Yuri definitely didn't look happy.
Yuri will have to answer for his crimes, Kapitan. I will never forgive him for putting your life in danger. What would I... what would the crew do without you?
Well, I'm still here, Voroshilov - don't worry.
I have to thank you again for showing me all those hobbies. There is so much to learn about the world, and I am happy you are guiding me. I am sorry I was so resistant at first...
It's okay, Voroshilov - it must be tough being watched by the Party from the moment you came into this world. It's hard to live a normal life when you have no freedom.
Da - I am glad I started to understand true freedom once Yuri was no longer monitoring me.
*FOOTSTEPS*
Zdravstvuyte, Kapitan. I am Mikhail Petrov. The Party has sent me to join your ship - in replacement of Yuri Ivanovich.

Fields.MenuText: I guess the Party will never stop watching Voroshilov, huh?
I hope you'll be better behaved than Yuri was...
Voroshilov can't read Marshal Voroshilov's mind! When will the Party accept that?

Fields.DialogueText: The data is still inconclusive, but the potential threat to security is still there, Kapitan. We are just taking all reasonable precautions.
It has come to light that Yuri Ivanovich betrayed the Party on several occasions. My only duty is to monitor Comrade Voroshilov and report what I see to the Party, so there will be no difficulties.
She still has dreams of Marshall Voroshilov's memories, Kapitan. This is already a security threat, even if her mind reading capabilities are still unproven.
Well, if you have official Party orders to join us, all I can say is welcome aboard, Mikhail Petrov.
Spasiba, Kapitan.
I look forward to getting to know you, Comrade Voroshilov.
... and I look forward to getting to know you, Mikhail Petrov...
Rusalki in the harbor, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
And, I have to say, with Yuri no longer monitoring, I was hoping that-
